questions.question_text:
A junior systems administrator is scanning archive.tar files with an antivirus scanner. The administrator is given the following tasks:
✑ List all files that are in the archive.tar files.
✑ Extract all files from the archive.tar files.
Which of the following actions should be performed to meet these requirements? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Listing Tar Archives
When used with the --list (-t) option, the tar command lists the content of a tar archive without extracting it.

$ tar -tf archive.tar

Extracting Tar Archive
Most of the archived files in Linux are archived and compressed using a tar or tar.gz format. Knowing how to extract these files from the command line is important.

$ tar -xf archive.tar
The dropdown on the right does not show all the options. However the correct and only answer is systemctl restart nginx to resolve the issue.

The left box may be commands you can select to view their output, but the way this question is worded and setup, it makes it seem like different commands are being run. I think the overall point of the question is to ask the person "What do you do after all of these other commands are run"?
This question is confusing. Who actually understands this?
This seems dorked up. Anyone have any thoughts?

questions.question_text: A corporate server security policy states, `Ensure password hashes are not readable by non-administrative users.` The administrator should check the permissions on which of the following files to ensure the server satisfies this policy?

discussion.content: hashes are stored in the shadow files...

Selected Answer: A
A is the one

Only users with root privledges can read /etc/shadow ... but non admins can read /etc/passwd. No telling what the jerkwads at CompTIA are looking for, but I'm changing my choice from /e/s IA) to /e/p (B)

comments.content: This is not a normal case and only leads to confusion for people studying this exam.

so o0o0, what you are saying is that read permissions shouldnt be on the /etc/passwd file for anyone other than admins... hmmm... 
*sarcastic* "Na man, totally agree with you... in fact you go make that change on the production environment ASAP..."

Let me ask you, what is listed in the /etc/passwd besides the old location where passwords were stored? Dont you think that information is important for the users account to reference during login? How about you test your hypothesis. # sudo chmod o-r /etc/passwd

discussion.content: the trick here is non administrative users....Bad configuration can store hashes in the /etc/passwd file as well. The later bein accessible to non admin users.

choices.C: echo ג€service network restartג€ | at now

discussion.content: nohup - "Used to execute a child process without parent association."

questions.question_text:
An administrator needs to change the IP address on a server remotely. After updating the configuration files, a network restart is needed. However, the administrator fears that when the network connection drops, the network restart script will be killed before the new IP address has been set.
Which of the following commands would prevent the script from being killed?

comments.content: yeah, it states implementation for files required for httpd, creating a repo would be first step.

discussion.content:
Correct Answer: B. Create a new repository using ג€˜git initג€™

git-init - Create an empty Git repository or reinitialize an existing one

git-config - Get and set repository or global options

questions.question_text: A Linux systems administrator is implementing Source Code Management for the web application server configuration files located in /etc/httpd/. Which of the following steps should the administrator perform FIRST?

choices.A: Clone the remote repository using 'git clone'
choices.D: Configure the directory for git using 'git config'
choices.B: Create a new repository using 'git init'
choices.C: Retrieve the remote changes using 'git commit'
